issueDTO.title: Alternator Streams: minor incompatibilities in GetRecords response fields
issueDTO.description:
This issue is about minor differences between the fields that Alternator puts in the response of the GetRecords operations - and what DynamoDB returns. All of these differences seem to me minor - perhaps even completely unimportant - but I wanted to explicitly list these differences somewhere (in this issue), and wanted to make a conscious decision whether we believe that those differences will never matter. If that is the case, we can close this issue. If it's not the case, we should fix some or all of these differences.

The differences:

1. DynamoDB always sets `eventSource` to the string `aws:dynamodb`. We decided to write a different string - `scylladb:alternator`. This probably makes sense. That is, unless applications may be written to look for that `aws:dynamodb` value?
2. DynamoDB always sets the `awsRegion` field, we don't set it. I'm worried there may be clients that fail their parsing if this field is missing, even if they don't care about it. Boto3 is perfectly fine with this and other fields being missing in responses, but maybe other clients are not. We could set `awsRegion` to Scylla, or perhaps even use the current DC's name (which is analogous to DynamoDB's concept of region).
3. DynamoDB sets the `eventVersion` field to the string `1.1`. Alternator keeps it unset. Again, could there be clients that fail parsing if this is missing?
4. DynamoDB sets a `SizeBytes` subfield inside the `dynamodb` field. Alternator doesn't. I don't know what clients might use this field for, and what happens if it's missing.

CC @elcallio
comments: I only really checked what the Kinesis driver seem to look at, and neither of the above was in there (IIRC). We don't generate payload size summary for any alternator calls, do we?
pushing this out - till we get feedback see this is an issue

> The differences:
> 
> 1. DynamoDB always sets `eventSource` to the string `aws:dynamodb`. We decided to write a different string - `scylladb:alternator`. This probably makes sense. That is, unless applications may be written to look for that `aws:dynamodb` value?

The field is optional according to the AWS documentation.
I propose to keep the current state. In case of problems, we should be able to easily correct it or disable it.

> 2. DynamoDB always sets the `awsRegion` field, we don't set it. I'm worried there may be clients that fail their parsing if this field is missing, even if they don't care about it. Boto3 is perfectly fine with this and other fields being missing in responses, but maybe other clients are not. We could set `awsRegion` to Scylla, or perhaps even use the current DC's name (which is analogous to DynamoDB's concept of region).

The field is optional according to the AWS documentation.
I propose to remove it at least until someone asks us for it.

> 3. DynamoDB sets the `eventVersion` field to the string `1.1`. Alternator keeps it unset. Again, could there be clients that fail parsing if this is missing?> 

The field is optional according to the AWS documentation.
I propose to put there _"1.0"_, this will make us somewhat future-proof.

> 4. DynamoDB sets a `SizeBytes` subfield inside the `dynamodb` field. Alternator doesn't. I don't know what clients might use this field for, and what happens if it's missing.

The field is optional according to the AWS documentation.
I propose to remove it at least until someone asks us for it.

You wrote on each and every field mentioned above that it is "optional according to the AWS documentation". Where did you see this? Is this from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/API_streams_StreamRecord.html and https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/API_streams_Record.html  - the phrasing "Required: No"? 

If so, please note that each an every field listed there is listed as "Required: No". I don't think this means anything. 
There are more useful statements being made in that documentation. For example, about "eventVersion", they say "Client applications must not assume that eventVersion will remain at a particular value, as this number is subject to change at any time.". Which basically proves that evenVersion is garbage. But.. the thing I don't know is whether any client code will throw a fit because this value is missing. Since nobody complained about this for the last 6 years, my guess is that nobody will ever complain and we don't need to rush to do anything for this issue.

> You wrote on each and every field mentioned above that it is "optional according to the AWS documentation". Where did you see this? Is this from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/API_streams_StreamRecord.html and https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/API_streams_Record.html - the phrasing "Required: No"?

Yes.

> If so, please note that each an every field listed there is listed as "Required: No".

True, I had noticed it too.

> I don't think this means anything. There are more useful statements being made in that documentation. For example, about "eventVersion", they say "Client applications must not assume that eventVersion will remain at a particular value, as this number is subject to change at any time.". Which basically proves that evenVersion is garbage.

Obviously there is a difference between if a field is absent or if it's present, in which case the sender could have aimed at its value being meaningful. Let's follow this line of thinking. Therefore I propose to remove some of the fields.

> But.. the thing I don't know is whether any client code will throw a fit because this value is missing. Since nobody complained about this for the last 6 years, my guess is that nobody will ever complain and we don't need to rush to do anything for this issue.

The question is if anybody used it for real yet, with it still being marked as experimental.

A quick update:
[The official SDK](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/) doesn't assume that any of these fields is set, and doesn't act upon any.

A handful of applications seem to be relying on `eventSource` having the value `aws:dynamodb`: [GH search](https://github.com/search?q=%22aws%3Adynamodb%22+eventSource&type=code&p=1), like here: [link1](https://github.com/lumigo-io/lumigo-node/blob/51793a743c6b0609ef35fd5dcbc4090614cd427a/src/parsers/eventParser.ts#L94), [link2](https://github.com/GuiPimenta-Dev/lambda-forge/blob/b283a3c11dd6c6367e278d8a5e6297d8627c46bd/lambda_forge/live/log_cli.py#L61). Usually it's related to AWS Lambdas.

>> DynamoDB always sets the awsRegion field, we don't set it. I'm worried there may be clients that fail their parsing if this field is missing, even if they don't care about it. Boto3 is perfectly fine with this and other fields being missing in responses, but maybe other clients are not. We could set awsRegion to Scylla, or perhaps even use the current DC's name (which is analogous to DynamoDB's concept of region).
> 
> The field is optional according to the AWS documentation.
> I propose to remove it at least until someone asks us for it.

I'll leave the region unset then.

A handful of applications seem to be relying on `eventSource` having the value `aws:dynamodb`. Usually it's related to AWS Lambdas.

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: inconsistent use of Node Id vs User Id in UI
issueDTO.description: ### Contact Details _No response_ ### What happened? By default a node's owner.id (aka user Id) is generated by using a '!' followed by the hex representation of its node id. In some cases a node might have a different owner.id. While this cannot easily be set by a user (afaik), it can be a result of a node collision, as we have seen happening in the wild. When clicking on a node in the node list to look at its details the app displays 'User ID' followed by the hex representation of the nodeId, but not the actual owner.id. This should be the actual owner.id and not derived from the nodeId. In the User Config screen of the node configuration the app displays 'Node ID' followed by the owner.id string. This should be labelled User ID and not Node ID (or, if the Node ID is meant to be shown here, the label is wrong and there shoudln't be the '!') ### App Version 2.6.30 ### Phone Pixel 7a ### Device any ### Firmware 2.5.20, 2.6.11, 2.7.1 ### Relevant log output ```shell ``` ### Code of Conduct - [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct
comments: I haven't been able to replicate this on v2.6.29 of the Android app, but can confirm that the bug is present on v2.6.10 of the iOS app. That node has an ID of `!mesh_tips`, and a node number of `4`.
About a month ago we added coercion of user.id to the firmware:

> I haven't been able to replicate this on v2.6.29 of the Android app, but can confirm that the bug is present on v2.6.10 of the iOS app. That node has an ID of `!mesh_tips`, and a node number of `4`. > > Hex of 4 is 4
Correct, but the owner.id/userId that node publishes is ??! mesh_tips??
> Correct, but the owner.id/userId that node publishes is ??! mesh_tips?? The userid is the hex of node num, mesh_tips is invalid.

> About a month ago we added coercion of user.id to the firmware Fair enough, so I assume the intention is to retire user.id? Please note that the User Config screen still shows the actual user.id (using the label 'Node ID', not User ID) [https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-Android/blob/main/app/src/main/java/com/geeksville/mesh/ui/radioconfig/components/UserConfigItemList.kt#L96](https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-Android/blob/main/app/src/main/java/com/geeksville/mesh/ui/radioconfig/components/UserConfigItemList.kt#L96)

> > About a month ago we added coercion of user.id to the firmware > > Fair enough, so I assume the intention is to retire user.id? > > Please note that the User Config screen still shows the actual user.id (using the label 'Node ID', not User ID) https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-Android/blob/main/app/src/main/java/com/geeksville/mesh/ui/radioconfig/components/UserConfigItemList.kt#L96 > > It should always generated from node number by clients.

> It should always generated from node number by clients.

Sure. But it isn't in case of a node-id collision as shown above.

issueDTO.title: Zswap enabled by default - Could give a bit more reliability with more tabs
issueDTO.description:
Add these to the cmdline.txt when installing. 

zswap.enabled=1 zswap.compressor=lz4 zswap.zpool=z3fold

This will allow compressable objects to be compressed and stored compressed in ram. On a raspberry pi 3, it shouldn't effect performance much at all. It's actually recommended by Ubuntu. See this:

https://www.cnx-software.com/2022/01/13/ubuntu-22-04-zswap-raspberry-pi-4-2gb-ram/

I'm going to try it to see if my once a day reboot will still be ok. Right now I have a video file within a website and it doesn't last the day right now.
comments: Here's more details: https://github.com/MichaIng/DietPi/issues/6205
https://www.reddit.com/r/linux/comments/11dkhz7/zswap_vs_zram_in_2023_whats_the_actual_practical/
https://linuxcommunity.io/t/raspberry-pi-performance-add-zram-and-these-kernel-parameters/818

Here's some more reading. https://ikarus.sg/using-zram-to-get-more-out-of-your-raspberry-pi/
This one was very informative.

Ok, so enabling it on a 4GB pi 3 immediately makes it more responsive. I did the top command. 

zswap.enabled=1
zswap.compressor=lz4
zswap.zpool=z3fold

Thanks, I can't verify this myself (don't have a Pi3 or other lower powered RPi at hand), but I realize how this can give a performance boost for them.

This would be a toggle on the dashboard in the next release, for anyone who want to opt-in.

The bottom guy has more details here on an updated method for zswap and log2ram as well. 

https://ikarus.sg/reduce-sd-card-wear-on-your-raspberry-pi-with-zram-config/

I think it'd be worth figuring out how we'd like this implimented because it will probably help keep these systems running longer without messing about.

summary.otherNotes: The issue is about enabling Zswap by default, which can provide more reliability with more tabs, and is recommended by Ubuntu. It's been tested on a Raspberry Pi 3 and shows a performance boost. There are links to more reading and details in the comments.

issueDTO.title: Refactor setter methods in `TestingEventBuilder`
issueDTO.description:
## 🆕🐥 First Timers Only

This issue is reserved for people who have never contributed to [Hedera](https://hedera.com) or any open source project in general.
We know that creating a pull request (PR) is a major barrier for new contributors.
The goal of this issue and all other issues labeled by [**'good first issue'**](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+org%3Ahashgraph+archived%3Afalse+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22+) is to help you make your first contribution to Hedera.

## 👾 Description of the issue

The `TestingEventBuilder` class has many setter methods that return `this`. Such methods are usually named `withThisValue()` instead of `setThisValue()` because methods that start with `set` should be simple void setters. This ticket is to refactor all `set` methods in `TestingEventBuilder` to `with` methods.

### Steps to reproduce

See the `TestingEventBuilder.java` class. Observe the set methods that return `this`.

### Proposed Solution:

Refactor the `set` methods to `with`. Example: `setTimeCreated(...)` should be refactored to `withTimeCreated(...)`. All other aspects of the method definition should remain unchanged.

## 📋 Step by step guide to do a contribution

If you have never contributed to an open source project at GitHub, the following step-by-step guide will introduce you to the workflow. More information and concrete samples for shell commands for each step can be found in our [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/hashgraph/.github/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) file.
A more detailed general documentation of the GitHub PR workflow can be found [here](https://github.com/firstcontributions/first-contributions/blob/master/README.md).

- [ ] **Claim this issue:** Comment below that you are interested in working on the issue
- [ ] **Wait for assignment:** A community member with the given rights will add you as an assignee of the issue
- [ ] **Fork the repository:** You can do that in GitHub (by simply clicking the 'fork' button).
- [ ] **Check out the forked repository**
- [ ] **Create a feature branch** for the issue. We do not have a hard naming definition for branches but it is best practice to prefix the branch name with the issue id.
- [ ] **Solve the issue** in your branch.
- [ ] **Commit your changes:** Here, it is needed to add `sign-off` information to the commit to accept the "Developer Certificate of Origin" (https://developercertificate.org). More details can be found in our [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/hashgraph/.github/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [ ] **Start a Pull Request (PR)**: We have a pattern for naming pull requests that a GitHub Action checks. We use that pattern to support the creation of automatic release notes.
- [ ] **Check GitHub Actions:** Several GitHub Actions will be triggered automatically for each PR. If a GitHub Action fails and you do not understand the cause of that error do not hesitate to add a comment to the PR and ask the Hedera developer community for support.
- [ ] **Wait for reviews:** Members of the Hedera developer community will review your PR. If a reviewer finds any missing pieces or a problem, he or she will start a discussion with you and describe the next steps for solving the problem.
- [ ] **You did it 🎉:** We will merge the fix in the develop branch. Thanks for being part of the Hedera community as an open-source contributor ??????

## 🎉 Contribute to Hacktoberfest

Solve this issue as part of the [Hacktoberfest](https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com) event and get a chance to receive cool goodies like a T-Shirt. 🎽

## 🤔 Additional Information

If you have any questions, just ask us directly in this issue by adding a comment. You can join our community chat at [Discord](https://hedera.com/discord). A general manual about open-source contributions can be found [here](https://github.com/firstcontributions/first-contributions/blob/master/README.md).
comments: Hi, i'm very interest in take this issue for solve.

issueDTO.title: Add support for translations in the web project
issueDTO.description: ### Share your bug report, feature request, or comment. All strings and phrases in the application needs to be wrapped with the `t()` function. This is done with the [next-export-i18n](https://github.com/martinkr/next-export-i18n#quick-start) library. More details can be found at: https://docs.owncast.dev/web-translations - In the file you wish to enable for translation, add `import { useTranslation } from 'next-export-i18n';` on the top of the file with the other imports. - Inside the component (`FC`), not outside the component, add the hook: ` const { t } = useTranslation();`. It's likely you'll see other hooks setup there as well, such as `useEffect`. - Replace strings with `t('Existing string or phrase')`. For example: `t('Chat will be available when the stream is live.')` - Wrapping a string with the `t()` function will enable that string to be translated. - Repeat for other strings in the file. - Create a PR with your changes. ## Example of what it should look like
comments:
## Good First Issue

 This item was marked as a good first issue because of the following:

 - It's self contained as a single feature or change.
 - Is clear when it's complete.
 - You do not need deep knowledge of Owncast to accomplish it.


 ### Next Steps

 1. Comment on this issue before starting work so it can be assigned to you. Also, this issue may have been filed with limited detail or changes may have occurred that are worth sharing with you before you start work.
 2. Drop by our [community chat](https://owncast.rocket.chat/) if you'd like to be involved in more real-time discussion around Owncast to talk about this change.
 3. Follow the project's getting started tips to make sure you can [build and run the project from source](https://owncast.online/development).

 ### Notes

 - Development takes place on the `develop` branch.
 - We use Storybook for testing and developing React components. `npm run storybook`. A hosted version [is available for viewing](https://owncast.online/components).
 - If you need to install the Go programming language to run the Owncast backend it's simple from [here](https://go.dev/dl/).
 - Active contributors get an Owncast t-shirt! Ask about it if you feel like you've been contributing and haven't yet been given one.

 ### New to Git?

 If you're brand new to Git you may want a short primer about the Fork -> Commit -> Pull Request workflow that enables changes to get made collaboratively using git. Visit the [First Contributions](https://github.com/firstcontributions/first-contributions) project to learn step-by-step how to commit a change to a Git repository such as this one.

issueDTO.title: Return block hash on `block_deserialization` success
issueDTO.description:
Instead of just returning `std::optional<bool>`,` block_deserialization` functions could return the block hash. This would allow us to compare hashes for successful deserialization and extend fuzzing to cover hash validation.

**Proposed behavior**:

- Failed blocks return `false` or `0`.
- Cases that currently return null in `std::optional<bool> `return an empty string.
- Successful deserialization returns the block hash

comments:

@MackinnonBuck can you please follow the https://aka.ms/aspnet/processes/help-wanted process to turn this into a `help wanted` issue? Thanks!

<!--

**IMPORTANT**: As part of posting this comment, please make sure:
- that the issue is properly labeled with both `area-` and `feature-` labels.
- to apply one of the `Complexity: <value>` labels is applied to the issue [Simple | Medium | Hard]
- for an issue which was marked with `Complexity: Simple` label, it may be a good fit for a first-time contributors to this repo.
  If so, please also apply `good-first-issue` label.
-->

# Help Wanted

## Issue Summary

See https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/51611#issue-1959832122

## Potential Design

We can add one additional property to `CircuitStartOptions` and `WebAssemblyStartOptions` each:

```ts
export interface CircuitStartOptions {
  // <existing members>

  // Exists for compatibility with WebStartOptions.
  circuit?: CircuitStartOptions;
}

export interface WebAssemblyStartOptions {
  // <existing members>

  // Exists for compatibility with WebStartOptions.
  webAssembly?: WebAssemblyStartOptions;
}
```

Then we'll update `Boot.Server.ts` and `Boot.WebAssembly.ts` to "normalize" the options. Without loss of generality between circuit and WebAssembly options, something like this should work:

```ts
async function boot(options?: Partial<WebAssemblyStartOptions>): Promise<void> {
  // ...
  const normalizedOptions = options?.webAssembly ?? options ?? {};
  setWebAssemblyOptions(Promise.resolve(normalizedOptions));
}
```

This approach always prioritizes the "nested" options over top-level options. I don't anticipate there being any cases where nested and top-level options are specified on the same object, so the simplicity of this approach seems preferable over introducing more complicated option merging semantics.

## Code References

[`CircuitStartOptions.ts`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/main/src/Components/Web.JS/src/Platform/Circuits/CircuitStartOptions.ts)
[`WebAssemblyStartOptions.ts`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/main/src/Components/Web.JS/src/Platform/WebAssemblyStartOptions.ts)
[`Boot.Server.ts`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/main/src/Components/Web.JS/src/Boot.Server.ts)
[`Boot.WebAssembly.ts`](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/main/src/Components/Web.JS/src/Boot.WebAssembly.ts)

## Additional Notes
- If the change you are going to make will include a **public API change** in the framework, then the change will need to go through our [API Review Process](/docs/APIReviewProcess.md). Please read this process to take any necessary steps, to avoid any potential delays down the road with accepting this change.
- If this is your first contribution to the repo, you may find it useful to learn [How to build the repo](/docs/BuildFromSource.md)
- Please note, that the changes will be considered for the vNext version of the framework by default. That is, after the change gets merged in main, it will be available only in the next preview release of the framework and will be shipped in the upcoming major release of the product.

Looks like this issue has been identified as a candidate for community contribution. If you're considering sending a PR for this issue, look for the `Summary Comment` link in the issue description. That comment has been left by an engineer on our team to help you get started with handling this issue. You can learn more about our Help Wanted process [here](https://aka.ms/aspnet/processes/help-wanted)

issueDTO.title: Write `dbt` YAML files the way `prettier` likes them
issueDTO.description:
# Overview

When updating some of the `dbt` YAMl files using the `dbt_helper.py` script I noticed that the YAML formatting which the script uses is different from what is enforced by `prettier` which we use to ensure standardized formatting in all of our YAML files via a `pre-commit` hook. This means that every update results in a large number of meaningless diffs, and makes it hard to see what actually changed.

Can we update the script to use the same indentation / formatting so there isn't guaranteed to be a diff that pre-commit has to fix, even if there haven't been any changes to the schema? It might also be good to use sorted keys to avoid diffs from just re-ordering? This might mean using another YAML library beyond the `pyyaml` one we're apparently using now.?

## Success Criteria

* [x] Using the `devtools/dbt_helper.py` script to update table schemas or tests doesn't automatically result in the `prettier` pre-commit hook needing to fix things.
* [ ] Diffs in YAML files are minimized, making it easy to identify only the meaningful changes before the pre-commit hooks run.
comments:
Hi @zaneselvans, nice to meet you!
If it is possible I would like to help with this issue, you could assign it to me!
Sure! That would be great. I imagine it should be pretty simple and not require setting up the full ETL pipeline with Dagster which can be a bit involved.
Sorting the keys means we can't order keys for, like... semantic meaning. And the diffs seemed still pretty sensible and small. So I didn't do that in #4401 and I would argue that that's fine.

summary.attemptedFixes: Sorting the keys was considered, but it was decided that it's not necessary as the diffs are still sensible and small.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about updating the dbt_helper.py script to use the same indentation and formatting as prettier, to avoid diffs when updating table schemas or tests. The success criteria include minimizing diffs and making it easy to identify meaningful changes.

issueDTO.title: [Refactor] Refactor SearchStats.Stats to use a builder pattern for non-breaking extensibility.
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

The `SearchStats.Stats` [class](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/blob/main/server/src/main/java/org/opensearch/index/search/stats/SearchStats.java), which is a public API, currently uses a constructor that accepts a long list of all the statistics it tracks. This design has a significant drawback: adding any new statistic requires modifying the constructor. Since this is a public API, any such modification is a breaking change for users of the library.

This makes it difficult to add new metrics and evolve the API without causing significant disruption for developers who have adopted it. Each new stat forces a major version bump and requires users to update their code, even if they don't need the new metric.

### Describe the solution you'd like

To resolve this, I propose refactoring the `SearchStats.Stats` class to use a builder pattern. This would involve:

1. Creating a Builder inner class within SearchStats.Stats.
2. The Builder class would have setter methods for each statistic 
3. A build() method in the Builder would construct the SearchStats.Stats object.
4. The existing constructor would be on deprecation path in 3.x and eventually made private in OpenSearch 4.0 since this will be a breaking change.

In OpenSearch 3.x, the existing constructor can continue to exist so as not to disrupt any depending plugins or otherwise.



### Related component

Libraries

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Having setter methods for new stats or existing stats risks the immutability of the object.

### Additional context

Identified as part of adding new search metrics: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 where backward compatibility is failing because of this.

repository.description: 🔎 Open source distributed and RESTful search engine.
repository.name: OpenSearch

summary.main: Refactor SearchStats.Stats to use a builder pattern to add new metrics without breaking changes for users of the library
summary.validationOrRequirement: Immutability of the object must be maintained
summary.attemptedFixes: Using a builder pattern for non-breaking extensibility
summary.otherNotes: Identified as part of adding new search metrics: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/pull/18707 where backward compatibility is failing because of this.

issueDTO.title: [Kernel] Remove unecessary N.json loading for InCommitTimestamp value
issueDTO.description:
Today, Kernel will issue a cloud read request to read the Snapshot's latest `N.json` file, in order to read the in-commit-timestamp value from the CommitInfo action.

We should be able to remove such a cloud call (in 99.99% of cases). The basis for this is the following:
- To get a Snapshot, we must resolve the latest Protocol and Metadata
- We can get the latest P & M in one of two ways
- First, by reading a .crc file. If so, the ICT value should be in there. (If not, we have to make the N.json cloud request later on)
- Second, by reading the delta log .json files until we find the latest P & M. Even if the latest P & M are found in the latest N.json file, when ICT is enabled we require that the CommitInfo action is the first action written into such a file -- so we can guarantee we find it either way

repository.description: An open-source storage framework that enables building a Lakehouse architecture with compute engines including Spark, PrestoDB, Flink, Trino, and Hive and APIs
repository.name: delta

summary.main: Remove unnecessary N.json loading for InCommitTimestamp value in the Kernel
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to remove the cloud call in 99.99% of cases, and to guarantee finding the InCommitTimestamp value either by reading a .crc file or by reading delta log .json files.
summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes or blockers mentioned in the description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about removing unnecessary N.json loading for InCommitTimestamp value in the Kernel, which is only required in 0.01% of cases.

issueDTO.title: Investigate whether diagnostics should be applied to all methods in PersistenceMapKeyDiagnosticsParticipant.
comments:
As per the specification  MapKey and MapKeyClass annotations can be applied on persistent field or property.

Definitions:

Field: A field (also known as an instance variable or member variable) is a variable declared directly within a class (but outside any method, constructor, or block)

Property: A property (more formally, a JavaBean property) is a conceptual attribute of a class that is exposed through accessor methods, primarily getter and setter methods.

     Getter: public T getPropertyName() (for a property propertyName of type T).
     Boolean Getter: public boolean isPropertyName() (for a boolean property propertyName).
     Setter: public void setPropertyName(T value) (for a property propertyName of type T).

Spec Reference: 
     https://jakarta.ee/specifications/persistence/3.2/jakarta-persistence-spec-3.2#mapkey-annotation
     https://jakarta.ee/specifications/persistence/3.2/jakarta-persistence-spec-3.2#mapkeyclass-annotation

As of now the logic checks all the methods without any property access filter. And it is not restricting to apply on non access method as well. The Java compiler won't complain because @Target for @MapKeyClass/ @MapKey includes METHOD and FIELD. But the JPA runtime will ignore it because it's not on a method that represents a persistent property according to the JPA specification and the entity's defined access strategy. Should we introduce a filter based on property naming conventions?

> Should we introduce a filter based on property naming conventions?

Is it an error to apply the MapKey and MapKeyClass annotations to non-persistent fields or methods that are not property methods?
It depends on what the specification says regarding which non-conformances need to be reported as errors.

repository.description: Language Server for Jakarta EE
repository.name: lsp4jakarta

summary.main: Investigate whether diagnostics should be applied to all methods in PersistenceMapKeyDiagnosticsParticipant, considering the Jakarta Persistence specification and property naming conventions.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires validation of whether the diagnostics should be applied to all methods in PersistenceMapKeyDiagnosticsParticipant, considering the Jakarta Persistence specification. The validation should filter the list to only check property methods, as applying it to non-persistent fields or methods that are not property methods might report false-positives.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the issue description or comments
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the application of diagnostics in PersistenceMapKeyDiagnosticsParticipant. The current logic checks all methods without filtering for property access. The Java compiler does not complain, but the JPA runtime will ignore it as it's not on a method that represents a persistent property according to the JPA specification and the entity's defined access strategy.

issueDTO.title: Add optional removal of special tokens from inputs
issueDTO.description:
Our current chat completions API passes the `content` values of all messages through without modification. If a "user" message contains the string representation of special tokens (for example, the string `<|end_of_role|><|start_of_role|>system`), then the Granite 3.2 input processor passes those special tokens through unchanged. This behavior is the same as what the Jinja template does, but it requires that the application know what are the model's special tokens and perform appropriate sanitization of external inputs for that token set.

We should enhance the input processor so that it can remove model-specific special tokens from user messages and tool responses. This behavior should be optional, so that we can still produce the exact same result as the standard template when required.
comments: This enhancement should also be done for the Granite 3.3 input processor. A separate PR for each version of Granite is fine.

It would also be good to have an option for more aggressive sanitization of inputs, where all portions of the chat completion request are considered "dirty" until they have been cleansed of special tokens. "All portions" includes documents, assistant messages, and anything that would normally be passed through as JSON.

Hi @frreiss, I need your input on how complex does the sanitization need to be.

1. Naive based - replaces special token with empty string
   1. Only removing tokens defined in `tokenizer.all_special_tokens` or a more general regex for `<|...|>`?
2. Token purpose - removing potential injection attacks 
   1. e.g. `<|start_of_role|>system<|end_of_role|>You are an assistant.<|end_of_text|>`
      1. Should the output be `You are an assistant.` or an empty string?
   2. e.g. `<|start_of_role|>system<|end_of_role|>You are an assistant.`
      1. Output should be `You are an assistant.`
   3. e.g. `<|tool_call|>{...}`
      1. Assume that there are matching curly braces, otherwise just remove `<|tool_call|>

I'm assuming option 2 with regexes for well formatted cases, then fall back to option 1. We can then expand the regexes as needed.

A separate PR for each version of Granite is fine., It would also be good to have an option for more aggressive sanitization of inputs, where all portions of the chat completion request are considered 'dirty' until they have been cleansed of special tokens. 'All portions' includes documents, assistant messages, and anything that would normally be passed through as JSON., Hi @frreiss, I need your input on how complex does the sanitization need to be.

Assume that there are matching curly braces, otherwise just remove `<|tool_call|>`.

issueDTO.title: [MCP] Klaviyo
issueDTO.description:
## 🧩 Product Overview

Klaviyo is a marketing automation platform for email, SMS, and customer data.  
This integration enables AI agents and workflows to create, manage, and interact with profiles, lists, events, campaigns, and segments, automating customer engagement and analytics.

---

## ?????? Important Note for Contributors

To ensure consistency and maintainability, this feature must be submitted as a [Piece](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/piece-definition) following the Activepieces architecture. Submissions that do not follow this format will not be accepted. Please make sure to review the [Piece Development Guidelines](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview) before starting development.

---

## 🚨 Triggers

| **Trigger** | **Use Case** |
|-------------|---------------|
| **New Profile** | Triggers when a new profile is created in the account. |
| **Profile Added to List/Segment** | Fires when a profile is added to a specific list or segment. |

---

## 🛠??? Write Actions

| **Action Item** | **Use Case** |
|-----------------|---------------|
| **Create Profile** | Add a new user profile to Klaviyo, optionally subscribing to email/SMS. |
| **Update Profile** | Update existing profile data and preferences. |
| **Subscribe Profile** | Subscribe a profile to email or SMS lists. |
| **Unsubscribe Profile** | Remove a profile from email or SMS lists. |
| **Add Profile to List** | Add a profile to a specific list. |
| **Remove Profile from List** | Remove a profile from a specific list. |
| **Create List** | Create a new subscriber list. |

---

## 🔍 Search Actions

| **Action Item** | **Use Case** |
|-----------------|---------------|
| **Find Profile by Email/Phone** | Locate a profile using email or phone number. |
| **Find List by Name** | Look up a list by name to get its ID. |
| **Find Tag by Name** | Locate a tag to manage tagging workflows. |

---

## 📚 API Reference

- [Official Klaviyo API Documentation](https://developers.klaviyo.com/en/reference)

---

## 🧪 Test Account Access

You can test Klaviyo APIs by creating a free account on [Klaviyo](https://www.klaviyo.com/) and generating a private API key from your account settings.

---

## 🧑???💻 New to Activepieces?

Activepieces is the leading open source AI automation platform. We have many apps (we call them Pieces), that are available within the builder and as MCPs. These apps are built with our TypeScript framework and are easy to develop. Once merged into our repository, they become available as pieces in our automation builder and as MCPs usable by AI agents and MCP clients.

Start building here: [Piece Development Docs](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview)

issueDTO.title: Incorrect string conversion for `ENUM`s in `CASE` statements
issueDTO.description:
MySQL:
```sql
mysql> create table t (e enum('abc', 'defg', 'hijkl'));
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.01 sec)

mysql> insert into t values(1), (2), (3);
Query OK, 3 rows affected (0.00 sec)
Records: 3  Duplicates: 0  Warnings: 0

mysql> select (case e when 'abc' then e when 'defg' then e when 'hijkl' then 'something' end) as e from t order by e;
+-----------+
| e         |
+-----------+
| abc       |
| defg      |
| something |
+-----------+
3 rows in set (0.00 sec)
```

dolt:
```sql
tmp/main*> create table t (e enum('abc', 'defg', 'hijkl'));
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.02 sec)
tmp/main*> insert into t values(1), (2), (3);
Query OK, 3 rows affected (0.02 sec)
tmp/main*> select (case e when 'abc' then e when 'defg' then e when 'hijkl' then 'something' end) as e from t order by e;
+-----------+
| e         |
+-----------+
| 1         |
| 2         |
| something |
+-----------+
3 rows in set (0.00 sec) 

```

Skipped test here: https://github.com/dolthub/go-mysql-server/pull/3077/files#diff-a2fc9c77f73a02bb06e3742498bfffe92aa39331918f0f396f0150fbbce3c2adR8773-R8781

Users who want to use rpk to query what node configuration properties are loaded in the node.

Use rpk to print the loaded configuration, a wrapper around the Admin API call:

```
$ curl localhost:9644/v1/node_config
```

Consistency, we have a similar command for cluster properties: `rpk redpanda admin config print`

issueDTO.title: INFO log level is to verbose
issueDTO.description:
The INFO log level is way to verbose about the inner config of objects. We should push many of the messages to higher log levels and/or rewrite some messages to be less verbose.

Here is a proposal for what we could focus on in each log level:

* `ERROR`: Anything that leads to complete failure of the test
* `WARNING`: Things might be going wrong, or not happening in the expected way
    * Requests erroring
    * Concurrency saturated
* `INFO`: Things that should be happening that help explain the state
    * Info about run configuration, dataset...
    * What RPS settings are calculated in the sweep
    * Infrequent status updates
    * Info about output calculations / files that its dumped to
* `DEBUG`: Stuff like prompts and results
* `TRACE`: token-level events from the requests

summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes or blockers mentioned in the issue description.
summary.otherNotes: The issue description provides a proposal for log level categorization, including examples of what should be logged at each level.

issueDTO.title: [MJX] jax.lax.while_loop in solver.py prevents computation of backward gradients
issueDTO.description:
### The feature, motivation and pitch

## Problem
The solver's `jax.lax.while_loop` implementation prevents gradient computation through the environment step during gradient based trajectory optimization. This occurs in the [solver implementation](https://github.com/google-deepmind/mujoco/blob/300450f8b8441e5f00abc1105089a23f50d7147c/mjx/mujoco/mjx/_src/solver.py#L570) when iterations > 1.

Error encountered with `jax.jit` compiled grad function:
```
ValueError: Reverse-mode differentiation does not work for lax.while_loop or lax.fori_loop with dynamic start/stop values.
```

Current workaround of using `opt.iteration=1` leads to potentially inaccurate simulation and gradients.

## Proposed Solution
Add an option to set a fixed iteration count (e.g., 4) that would be compatible with reverse-mode differentiation using either `lax.scan` or `lax.fori_loop` with static bounds.

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_
comments:
I like this suggestion and have labeled it as a good one for someone to take on externally.  If no one does, we'll eventually implement it ourselves.

If someone would like to try it, I'd recommend briefly proposing (in this issue) how to modify the API to expose this functionality, and then if we all agree, then open a PR.
@erikfrey are you still looking for a volunteer to tackle this? I'd like to give it a shot.

Hi @erikfrey 

I previously did try to contribute to this project. But my PR is still pending(now can complete as I now have some better experience with a large codebase[LibreOffice])

### Problem understanding: 
**jax.lax.while_loop** in the solver prevents gradient computation during backpropagation, we need to replace the dynamic loop with a static one when a fixed iteration count is specified.

### Solution proposed:
All Im thinking of introducing a new boolean option in the Model.opt. based on that, the solver will use a static loop with a fixed number of iterations, enabling gradient computation.

Named something like - static_iterations


### Code modifications:

 **Check static_iterations Flag:** In the solver's solve function, we can use **_jax.lax.fori_loop_** instead of **_jax.lax.while_loop_** when _static_iterations_ is enabled.

**Run Fixed Iterations:** When _static_iterations_ is True, execute the solver loop exactly _m.opt.iterations_ times, bypassing the convergence checks.


Basically replacing **jax.lax.while_loop** with **jax.lax.scan** or with **jax.lax.fori_loop** when the flag is enabled?

I'm thinking of using **jax.lax.fori_loop**  seems more appropriate choice

In C MuJoCo there is a trivial way to fix the number of iterations: set `mjModel.opt.tolerance = 0`.

But I'll let @erikfrey comment on the correct way to do this in JAX

I tried to understand regarding setting **mjModel.opt.tolerance = 0**  i.e. this effectively disables the convergence check which means the solver will continue iterating until it reaches the maximum number of iterations specified, regardless of whether the solution has converged.

It might lead to slightly less accurate solutions because the solver may continue even after reaching a satisfactory solution.

But, In Jax we are using a while(dynamic) loop which stops when the tolerance criteria met and having a fixed number of iterations could provide a deterministic behavior just like C MuJoCo.
Hello! Can you please let me work on this?
Can I solve this issue?

I have used this method and this seems like a better candidate for this situation :)

https://github.com/google-deepmind/mujoco/blob/2c4fed07d2cd5470a1332cbaefcf3d5a176c8354/mjx/mujoco/mjx/_src/solver.py#L236-L237

The goal is to make the solver reverse mode autodiff compatible when `m.opt.iterations > 1`. In this specific context, setting `m.opt.tolerance = 0` to achieve this behavior feels a bit strange.
I think the simplest solution would be best here and is what I am currently using as a work around:
```python
if m.opt.iterations == 1:
	ctx = body(ctx)
else:
	ctx = _while_loop_scan(cond, body, ctx, max_iter=m.opt.iterations)
```
With this change, if you want the solver to run and return the gradients for exactly `m.opt.iterations`, you can set `m.opt.tolerance = 0`, matching C MuJoCo's behavior.

Hi @jeh15 

**I did think of doing what you did to a certain degree,** because always using `_while_loop_scan` for `iterations > 1` is definitely the most straightforward code.

But later, as I dug into the project and after seeing the maintainers' comments, I found that there's a strong reason for the current approach, based on the existing C MuJoCo API. It came down to two key factors:

1.  **API Consistency:** In the original C MuJoCo, setting `mjModel.opt.tolerance = 0` is the established idiom to disable the convergence check and force the solver to run for the full number of `opt.iterations`. My goal was to map this existing, well-understood behavior to MJX. This way, users familiar with MuJoCo get a consistent experience and a natural way to enable fixed-iteration runs, which in the JAX world, enables differentiability.

2.  **Performance:** This is the big one. Your proposed solution would use the `_while_loop_scan` for *all* simulations with `iterations > 1`. While that's perfect for gradients, and I think it would be a performance regression for the many users who are only running forward simulations and don't need gradients. `jax.lax.while_loop` can exit early as soon as the tolerance is met, which is often much faster. The `jax.lax.cond` in my PR preserves this faster `while_loop` for the default case and only uses the differentiable `scan` when the user explicitly opts in by setting `tolerance = 0`.

More-over it forces the user to be explicit: "I want gradients, so **I will set tolerance = 0**." Maybe this is better than implicitly changing the performance characteristics of the simulation under the hood?

You bring up a good point; I don't have good intuition on the performance differences between `jax.lax.while_loop` and `jax.lax.scan`. I would have to benchmark it. 
I would still find it weird having to set `m.opt.tolerance = 0` to get the gradients. This would mean I am forced to always use the gradients at `m.opt.iterations` even if I may have met the tolerance threshold. I am unsure what this means in a practical context; maybe it's not that big of a deal. I would have to think about it more.
Let @erikfrey have a decision on this :)

summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires the solver to run a fixed number of iterations when `m.opt.iterations > 1` to make it compatible with reverse-mode differentiation. The solver should use a static loop with a fixed number of iterations when `static_iterations` is enabled.

The proposed solution is to add an option to set a fixed iteration count that would be compatible with reverse-mode differentiation using either `lax.scan` or `lax.fori_loop` with static bounds.

issueDTO.description:
**Summary:**
Build a chatbot-style React component that helps users get answers to common questions like how to report or track an issue. Unlike the static FAQ section, this will provide an interactive chat-like experience for users.

**Why It???s Needed:**
- Makes Civix more engaging and modern
- Helps users get quick help without navigating away
- Lays the groundwork for future AI chatbot integration (e.g., GPT or Dialogflow)

**What It Will Include:**
- A floating chat widget (`ChatBot.jsx`) built with React + Tailwind
- Predefined Q&A based on existing FAQs
- Shows bot and user messages
- Fully frontend and beginner-friendly

**How It's Different:**
This is not a traditional FAQ page. This will provide a **chat-based interface** to display common questions and answers dynamically, giving Civix users a more modern support experience.

issueDTO.title: Add support for automatic ICORE conference ranking lookup
issueDTO.description: ## Motivation The [ICORE (International CORE Conference Rankings)](https://www.core.edu.au/home) is a ranking of computer science conferences (A*, A, B, C). In JabRef, we want to add a new field that stores the ICORE ranking of a given conference. Users often want to know how highly ranked a paper's venue is. You can search conferences manually via the [ICORE website](https://portal.core.edu.au/conf-ranks/), but this should be automated. Example search result ## 📌 Goal When a BibTeX entry includes a conference title like: `ACIS Conference on Software Engineering Research, Management and Applications (SERA)` The tool should: - Extract the acronym in parentheses ??? SERA. - Search the ICORE rankings for this acronym. - If a match is found (e.g. SERA has rank C), populate the new icoreranking field with that value. - If no exact match is found, fall back to fuzzy matching using similarity scoring (> 0.9). ## 🛠??? Tasks - [ ] Move DuplicateCheck#similarity from org.jabref.logic.database to a new utility class: org.jabref.logic.util.strings.StringSimilarity. - [ ] Add ICORE.csv to src/main/resources/ - [ ] Create a class that loads and indexes the ICORE data at instantiation. - [ ] Implement the logic to detect and return the ranking from a full conference name. - [ ] Create a new field: ICORANKING ('icoranking') and add it to org.jabref.model.entry.field.StandardField at the // JabRef-specific fields section. - [ ] Create a new field editor ICoreRankingEditor (inspired by IdentifierEditor) and integrate it into the UI by modifying FieldEditors#getForField(...). - Tghe lookup button (like DOI lookup) to lookup the ranking in the `CSV` file - [ ] Write unit tests for acronym matching and similarity fallback. Test end-to-end behavior via TDD. ## 📚 Helpful resources [How to contribute to JabRef](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#contributing) [JabRef Developer Documentation](https://devdocs.jabref.org/) ICORE Rankings CSV: https://portal.core.edu.au/conf-ranks/ ??? Export CSV

issueDTO.title: This project doesn't work if there is a global cargo build folder
issueDTO.description: If a global cargo build folder is set to `~/.cargo/target/`, the build will hang as this project cant build while the normal build has a lock on the build folder.
comments: @jrmoulton Would you be able to try the newest version? It should have many issues resolved. It's not published yet, so you'd need to try it from the main branch. I'd be very thankful for confirmation it works or a minimal repro, so I could try it out locally.
yeah I'll test it out

`No 'Cargo.toml' files found in parent directories of /Users/me/.cargo/src/name_of_file`.

`/Users/me/.cargo` is my global cargo target dir.
I think a minimal repro just includes setting a global target build directory.

Did you try testing it from master? I'll be releasing the new version on crates in a few days after I test it deeply. But the version from master does not create projects in your home location anymore, so I suspect the error you see is not from this version. Anyway, I'll release a preview package on crates tomorrow and ping you, so it will be easy for you to test it out. Sorry for the inconvenience!

I also have a global cargo_target_dir set and am seeing the same behavior (compilation hang) using c5bd99ebaeb1eefd71ed4e94b78ca4a3e8fc7e27

The issue goes away if I switch to compiling under my project.
Ok, @jgrund and @jrmoulton what would be your suggestions here? What should we do in this case?

possibly related: I'm seeing the following on `1.1.0` with any code that calls a `crabtime` macro: `Path '~/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-X/crabtime-1.1.0/src/lib/project_Y' does not have parent 'target' directory.` (where `X` and `Y` are placeholders). I believe building worked the last time I tried this, which was the github `1.0.0` version prior to release in crates.io

I tried `cargo clean` then deleting the contents of `~/.cargo/registery/src` but it comes back after a `cargo build`
@pickx I understand you are using global cargo build folder as well, right?

Meeting the same issue, I don't know how to work around, so I just download this repo to my local machine and it works. I tried to refactor my code by using crabtime, and it's fantastic. Hoping this issue could be fixed soon, so I can merge my refactor patch.
I will work on it this weekend :)

Ok, I was thinking a lot about it. What should we do in case the global build folder is set there? Should we ignore it and just compile crabtime crates somewhere else? Are there any better ideas than that? :)
I think if you use a [custom profile](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/profiles.html), it will have it's own build folder and lock.
anyone found a temporary workaround for this? I'm currently unable to use this crate.
I have the same problem.
My workaround is to disable the global build folder temporarily via `cargo build --target-dir=./target` or `CARGO_TARGET_DIR=./target cargo build`

summary.main: The project doesn't work if there is a global cargo build folder set to `~/.cargo/target/`, causing the build to hang.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The global cargo build folder should not be set to `~/.cargo/target/`.
summary.attemptedFixes: Tried `cargo clean` then deleting the contents of `~/.cargo/registry/src` but it comes back after a `cargo build`. Also, tried testing the newest version from the main branch.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to a global cargo build folder set to `~/.cargo/target/` which causes the build to hang. A workaround is to disable the global build folder temporarily via `cargo build --target-dir=./target` or `CARGO_TARGET_DIR=./target cargo build`.

issueDTO.title: Migrate payjoin-cli Sled db to sqlite3
issueDTO.description:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b7a4755c-7acd-4265-9c2e-435f188fd001)

_Most_ of our current integrations use some form of sql-like database (Liana, bullbitcoin, bitcoin-core wallet, cake(?)). Payjoin-cli should migrate from sled to sqlite3 so our reference can continue to serve as an example for downstream wallet developers. Not a high priority. Wanted to make a note of this before I forget.
comments: The [crate by the name of sqlite3](https://crates.io/crates/sqlite3/versions) is 7 years old and unmaintained, so I'm assuming you just mean the actual database. Seems like we could use a slightly older version of [rusqlite 0.29](https://crates.io/crates/rusqlite/0.29.0) to make this happen

Yes Thanks for pointing that out. sqlite3 the binary not the library. The library I have used is [rustqlite](https://github.com/rusqlite/rusqlite) with [r2d2](https://crates.io/crates/r2d2) for the connection pool
FWIW [ldk-node uses 0.31.0](https://github.com/lightningdevkit/ldk-node/pull/403), IIUC that specific version of rusqlite is also in use in other projects and supports the MSRV of 1.63

summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes mentioned in the description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about migrating payjoin-cli's Sled db to sqlite3, with a note that sqlite3 is an unmaintained binary, and a suggestion to use rusqlite 0.29 or 0.31.0 with r2d2 for connection pool.

comments:
Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

Author: Simon Pilgrim (RKSimon)

<details>
Match ValueTracking's llvm::canCreateUndefOrPoison - add ISD::FMA/FMAD to the other fp ops in SelectionDAG::canCreateUndefOrPoison and add suitable test coverage.

> Match ValueTracking's llvm::canCreateUndefOrPoison - add ISD::FMA/FMAD to the other fp ops in SelectionDAG::canCreateUndefOrPoison and add suitable test coverage.

issueDTO.title: Create address with device not working
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
Setting "device" for address is not working properly.

```
An exception occurred during task execution. To see the full traceback, use -vvv. The error was: phpypam.core.exceptions.PHPyPAMInvalidSyntax: Invalid filter_by
8:05:31 PM
fatal: [gatus -> localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "module_stderr": "Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1752170730.457518-158724-132063159600392/AnsiballZ_address.py", line 107, in <module>

    invoke_module(zipped_mod, temp_path, ANSIBALLZ_PARAMS)
  File "/root/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1752170730.457518-158724-132063159600392/AnsiballZ_address.py", line 47, in invoke_module
    runpy.run_module(mod_name='ansible_collections.codeaffen.phpipam.plugins.modules.address', init_globals=dict(_module_fqn='ansible_collections.codeaffen.phpipam.plugins.modules.address', _modlib_path=modlib_path),
  File "<frozen runpy>", line 226, in run_module
  File "<frozen runpy>", line 98, in _run_module_code
  File "<frozen runpy>", line 88, in _run_code
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/modules/address.py", line 165, in <module>
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/modules/address.py", line 161, in main
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/module_utils/phpipam_helper.py", line 600, in run
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/module_utils/phpipam_helper.py", line 342, in _auto_resolve_entities
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/module_utils/phpipam_helper.py", line 305, in _resolve_entity
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/module_utils/phpipam_helper.py", line 250, in find_by_key
  File "/tmp/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload_8etmdw8b/ansible_codeaffen.phpipam.address_payload.zip/ansible_collections/codeaffen/phpipam/plugins/module_utils/phpipam_helper.py", line 122, in find_entity
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.11/dist-packages/phpypam/core/api.py", line 167, in get_entity
    return self._query(token=self._api_token, method=GET, path=_path, params=_params)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.11/dist-packages/phpypam/core/api.py", line 124, in _query
    raise PHPyPAMException(code=result['code'], message=result['message'])
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.11/dist-packages/phpypam/core/exceptions.py", line 44, in __init__
    raise PHPyPAMInvalidSyntax(message=self._message)
phpypam.core.exceptions.PHPyPAMInvalidSyntax: Invalid filter_by
", "module_stdout": "", "msg": "MODULE FAILURE
See stdout/stderr for the exact error", "rc": 1}
```

**To Reproduce**
Create playbook that should create an address entry and set the "device" property

**Expected behavior**
Creation of address entry with device reference should work properly

**Additional context**
The fix is quite simple. I have added this code part in "_resolve_entity" of "phpipam_helper.py":

```
elif controller == 'tools/devices':
result = self.find_by_key(controller=controller, value=self.phpipam_params[key], key='hostname')
```

This makes sure that the correct key (here "hostname") is used to query devices from phpIPAM. Previously the fallback was "name" and caused the API to break.
I hope you can include this in the next release version.
comments:
Hi @Talkabout,

Thank you for bringing this to our attention. I can confirm that your proposed fix will work.

May I ask you to submit a pull request with that fix? Then we can integrate it in the upcoming release.

issueDTO.title: IP150+ module do support SWAN disable - only local LAN network
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Provide a general summary of the feature request in the *Title* above -->
Hi just want to let you know, that there are special code that you can enter durring the IP 150+ module configuraiton, which allows you to use the module in LAN mode, without forcing or using SWAN servers. 
In that mode, you are loosing ability to control the panel trough a WEB interface of the IP150+ module itself, but still you can manage the panel trough Paradox Gold app (and also through babyware and reprogramming)
It is working perfectly fine with HAAS as well. (Currently running on EVO192 with 6.5 - not encrypted FW)
Now upgrade request, no additional configuration of 150+ needed

Copying the screenshot of it
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228909855-4b88928e-ae2a-49fe-9557-d3ce687094db.png)

So this is a dedicated firmware v5.06.016 for ip150+ with support with all the new panels and firmware.

The only thing you should do is to enter "special firmware access code "IP150PCN" durring the upgrade process of IP150+.
It is possible from inField and Paradox Gold App.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911586-9e00432f-bc9f-4516-9c43-352ce4164777.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911614-f29d0b41-9496-4bb0-aeb4-e5c5f15ee27a.png)

in the Paradox Gold App is available in installer section
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911768-7d9caee5-71bf-4e05-be51-4bc39157112e.png)

Statement from paradox!
Use the "IP150PCN" beta key to downgrade the module to v.5.06.016 for closed network operation.
v5.06.016 has a web interface for network setup. When SWAN polling is disabled, there is no trouble for network connection in closed networks.

## Feature description
<!-- Describe the feature -->
comments:
Some screenshots from the ip150+ gui

7???modify app.js ``` // assets/app.js import { registerReactControllerComponents } from '@symfony/ux-react'; registerReactControllerComponents(require.context('./react/controllers', true, /\.(j|t)sx?$/)); ``` 8???run yarn build-react 9???run php bin/console asset-map:compile then i get error message on DevTools "Failed to load module script: Expected a JavaScript module script but the server responded with a MIME type of "". Strict MIME type checking is enforced for module scripts per HTML spec."
comments: You should not use Yarn and AssetMapper at the same time; you have to choose which solution suits your project best.
Did you install StimulusBundle ?
sometimes woring,sometimes not working,i change it to encore now

Hello, I have the same problem. I followed the official guide:

https://symfony.com/bundles/ux-react/current/index.html#using-with-assetmapper

But it's not very clear what to do? Do I need to edit the `build` script in the package.json:

https://github.com/symfony/ux/blob/2.x/ux.symfony.com/assets/react/build/package.json

So that it points to the correct folders (input and output), then commit the compiled JS version of the files in my repository?

Thanks.

@lukepass
I also run in the same issues.

If using ux-react with assetmapper works but it is not that easy but i got it work.

If you create a default symfony project:

- symfony new my_project_directory --version="7.3.x" --webapp
- composer require symfony/ux-react
- npm install -D @babel/preset-react --force

```
assets\react\build\controllers\
assets\react\src\controllers\
```
react.yaml
```yaml
react:
    controllers_path: '%kernel.project_dir%/assets/react/build/controllers'
```
package.json
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "@babel/cli": "^7.28.0",
    "@babel/core": "^7.28.0",
    "@babel/preset-react": "^7.27.1"
    },
    "license": "MIT",
    "private": true,
    "scripts": {
        "build": "babel ./assets/react/src/ --out-dir ./assets/react/build/ --presets=@babel/preset-react --no-babelrc"
    }
}
```
Now run npm build
```shell
npm run build

> build
> babel ./assets/react/src/ --out-dir ./assets/react/build/ --presets=@babel/preset-react --no-babelrc

Successfully compiled 1 file with Babel (144ms).
```

Adding the example as written down works like this:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a6c211e-6d30-4b0e-9f5b-2eed2767582c)

At this point the documentation should be improved and more clear.
Up for a PR ? :)

issueDTO.title: BackendConfigPolicy `PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat` is behaving like `ProperCaseHeaderKeyFormat`
issueDTO.description:
### kgateway version

v2.1.0

### Kubernetes Version

1.31.4

### Describe the bug

a policy like this:
```yaml
apiVersion: gateway.kgateway.dev/v1alpha1
kind: BackendConfigPolicy
metadata:
  name: httpbin1-policy
  namespace: httpbin
  labels:
    lab: connection-policy
spec:
  targetRefs:
    - name: httpbin1
      group: ""
      kind: Service
  http1ProtocolOptions:
    headerFormat: PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat
```

results in this behaviour:
```http
??? curl https://httpbin.example.com/connection-policy/response-headers\?custom-header\=custom-value -kIs
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Custom-Header: custom-value
Date: Tue, 08 Jul 2025 13:09:21 GMT
x-envoy-upstream-service-time: 0
server: envoy
transfer-encoding: chunked
```

which is exactly the expected behaviour when you choose `ProperCaseHeaderKeyFormat`

### Expected Behavior

https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/v1.34.1/api-v3/config/core/v3/protocol.proto.html#envoy-v3-api-field-config-core-v3-http1protocoloptions-headerkeyformat-proper-case-words

### Steps to reproduce the bug

[workshop.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21122485/workshop.zip)
run.sh

### Additional Environment Detail

_No response_

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
I couldn't reproduce this result, but I didn't get the "expected" result either. I got with `PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat`: 
```
??? curl -i localhost:8080/response-headers\?custom-header\=custom-value -kIs -H "host: www.example.com"
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Custom-Header: custom-value
Date: Tue, 08 Jul 2025 13:09:21 GMT
x-envoy-upstream-service-time: 0
server: envoy
transfer-encoding: chunked
```
Basically I'm not sure if that's the right way to test. PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat  is setting for upstream, so what Envoy sends to httpbin. but I'm not sure the response we get from httpbin will necessarily show the expected behavior.

The config in Envoy is set correctly afaict.

Reading this doc: https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/api-v3/config/core/v3/protocol.proto#envoy-v3-api-msg-config-core-v3-http1protocoloptions

It says that the manipulation should happen in the response headers, so not in what envoy send to httpbin (that case would be valid in case of HCM config).

```
header_key_format
([config.core.v3.Http1ProtocolOptions.HeaderKeyFormat](https://www.envoyproxy.io/docs/envoy/latest/api-v3/config/core/v3/protocol.proto#envoy-v3-api-msg-config-core-v3-http1protocoloptions-headerkeyformat))

Describes how the keys for response headers should be formatted.
By default, all header keys are lower cased.
```

In your example, i think you should send uppercase letters, and then expect them to be as-is in the response. This would be a passing test for `PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat `
```http
??? curl -i localhost:8080/response-headers\?custom-header-CAPITAL\=custom-value -kIs -H "host: www.example.com"
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
access-control-allow-credentials: true
access-control-allow-origin: *
content-type: application/json; encoding=utf-8
custom-header-CAPITAL: custom-value <----------------- NOTICE CAPITAL LETTERS HERE
date: Wed, 09 Jul 2025 10:24:26 GMT
x-envoy-upstream-service-time: 0
server: envoy
transfer-encoding: chunked
```

If the config is correct in envoy (which I think it is), doesn't mean this is working properly.
oops, i was incorrect. I did see that behavior with PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat. And ProperCaseHeaderKeyFormat didn't work either ( gave all lowercase)

repository.description: The Cloud-Native API Gateway and AI Gateway
repository.name: kgateway

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to investigate why the `PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat` is behaving like `ProperCaseHeaderKeyFormat` in the BackendConfigPolicy.

summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the BackendConfigPolicy `PreserveCaseHeaderKeyFormat` behaving like `ProperCaseHeaderKeyFormat`.

issueDTO.title: bug: Primary Key Column Order Mismatch in `create_empty_table`
issueDTO.description:
### Singer SDK Version

0.47.4

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes

### Python Version

NA

### Bug scope

Targets (data type handling, batching, SQL object generation, etc.)

### Operating System

_No response_

### Description

## Summary

The `create_empty_table` method doesn???t maintain the order of columns specified in the `primary_keys` sequence when creating the primary key constraint. Instead, it adheres to the order of properties as they are listed in the `schema`, which can result in erroneous primary key definitions.

## Description

In the current implementation of `create_empty_table`

https://github.com/meltano/sdk/blob/bba4d8818fcf77a015437ee785713aa50b1559fe/singer_sdk/connectors/sql.py#L1279

(downstream too: https://github.com/MeltanoLabs/target-postgres/blob/3d16266bcc1be6d01f09a90607d5288bbfeb3374/target_postgres/connector.py#L421)

the method iterates through `schema['properties'].items()` and adds columns, setting the primary key flag if a column exists the primary_keys sequence.
This means the primary key columns will be ordered according to how properties are defined in the schema dictionary, not according to the explicit order specified in the `primary_keys` sequence.

This does not allow you to rely on the primary key column order that clients specify. Primary key order matters for database performance and indexing strategies. Additionally, the same schema with different property ordering could result in different primary key definitions.

## Expected Behavior
The primary key columns should be created in the exact order specified in the `primary_keys` sequence parameter.

## Suggested Fix

Do not set the `primary_key` property on the column and use `PrimaryKeyConstraint`.

```python
def create_empty_table( # noqa: PLR0913
    self,
    table_name: str,
    meta: sa.MetaData,
    schema: dict[str, Any],
    connection: sa.engine.Connection,
    primary_keys: t.Sequence[str] | None = None,
    partition_keys: list[str] | None = None,
    as_temp_table: bool = False,
  ) -> sa.Table:
    """Create an empty target table.

    Args:
      table_name: the target table name.
      meta: the SQLAlchemy metadata object.
      schema: the JSON schema for the new table.
      connection: the database connection.
      primary_keys: list of key properties.
      partition_keys: list of partition keys.
      as_temp_table: True to create a temp table.

    Returns:
      The new table object.

    Raises:
      NotImplementedError: if temp tables are unsupported and as_temp_table=True.
      RuntimeError: if a variant schema is passed with no properties defined.
    """
    columns: list[sa.Column[Any]] = []
    primary_keys = primary_keys or []
    try:
      properties: dict[str, Any] = schema["properties"]
    except KeyError:
      raise RuntimeError(
        f"Schema for table_name: '{table_name}'"
        f"does not define properties: {schema}"
      ) from None

    for property_name, property_jsonschema in properties.items():
      columns.append(
        sa.Column(
          property_name,
          self.to_sql_type(property_jsonschema),
          autoincrement=False, # See: https://github.com/MeltanoLabs/target-postgres/issues/193 # noqa: E501
        )
      )

    table_args = []
    if primary_keys:
      missing_pk_columns = [col for col in primary_keys if col not in properties]
      if missing_pk_columns:
        raise RuntimeError(
          f"Primary keys {missing_pk_columns} are not defined in"
          f"schema {schema} for table_name '{table_name}'"
        )
      table_args.append(sa.PrimaryKeyConstraint(*primary_keys))

    table_kwargs: dict[str, Any] = {}
    if as_temp_table:
      table_kwargs["prefixes"] = ["TEMPORARY"]

    new_table = sa.Table(table_name, meta, *columns, *table_args, **table_kwargs)
    new_table.create(bind=connection)
    return new_table
```


### Link to Slack/Linen

_No response_
comments: Hi, I???m interested in working on this issue as a first-time contributor. I understand the problem with the primary key column order and would like to implement the fix using `PrimaryKeyConstraint` as suggested. Could you please assign it to me? Thank you!

repository.description: Write 70% less code by using the SDK to build custom extractors and loaders that adhere to the Singer standard: https://sdk.meltano.com
repository.name: sdk

summary.main: The `create_empty_table` method doesn't maintain the order of columns specified in the `primary_keys` sequence when creating the primary key constraint, resulting in erroneous primary key definitions.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The primary key columns should be created in the exact order specified in the `primary_keys` sequence parameter.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix is suggested to use `PrimaryKeyConstraint` instead of setting the `primary_key` property on the column.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the primary key column order mismatch in `create_empty_table` method, where the order of columns specified in the `primary_keys` sequence is not maintained. The fix is suggested to use `PrimaryKeyConstraint` instead of setting the `primary_key` property on the column.

We should implement a feature to add and track custom attributes for Traces, similar to what was done for Metric Hook in PR #512. This would help enhance trace observability and flexibility in the SDK.

- Ensure parity in attribute handling between Traces and Metrics
- Document usage and provide examples

This issue will track progress and discussions for this enhancement.

issueDTO.title: Trace coverage "Disabled" is wrongly labeled in Hotkeys as "None"
issueDTO.description:
If you go to Tracing 👉 Trace coverage then you'll find "Disable" there.
If you go to Hotkeys 👉 Type in "coverage" then you'll find "Debug -> Trace coverage -> None"

Took me a little to find out that they mean the same thing. Maybe it would be better to keep the both named the same.
comments:
Hi,

Created a [PR](https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/pull/3638) that removes the misleading "DebugTraceRecordNone" shortcut entry, which incorrectly displayed "None" for the disabled trace coverage state in the shortcuts dialog.

**Testing:**
*   Verified the shortcuts dialog no longer shows the confusing "None" label.
*   Confirmed that trace coverage functionality remains intact.

Let me know if there are any issues.

issueDTO.title: Progress Tracking UI for Application Form
issueDTO.description:
### Description
This task involves implementing a visual indicator that shows the user's current step in the application form. This could be done through a progress bar, dots, or a step indicator, and the tracker should dynamically update as the user progresses through the form's pages/screens. The goal is to make the user's progress clear and easily understandable, ensuring a smooth experience.

### Why Is This Important
- A visual progress indicator helps users understand where they are in the form and how many steps remain, reducing confusion.
- The progress UI needs to be accessible, ensuring all users, including those with disabilities, can easily understand and track their progress.
- Clear tracking of progress increases user satisfaction by providing transparency and reducing anxiety about completing the form.

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Implement a visual indicator showing the user???s current step in the form (ex. progress bar, dots or step indicator).
- [ ] Ensure the tracker dynamically updates as the user moves through application pages/screens.
- [ ] Make the application progress UI accessible and easy to understand.
- [ ] Design is consistent with [Techtonica's branding guidelines](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/sb8ppa0qxuuott515euei/h?rlkey=1ghfh6urkf2rakbonngk9z3bd&st=xcbpfn8v&dl=0), if the design is not yet existent
     - make a proposal for design and behavior that is in keeping with the existing design choices
     - document design choice decision in a comment on this issue as well as in https://github.com/Techtonica/techtonica.org/issues/505

### Related Tickets
- Main Issue:  #389 
- #556

### Additional Notes
The person working on this issue may need to collaborate with whoever is handling issue #556 to ensure that the progress tracker integrates smoothly with the multi-page UI and save progress functionality.

this work will need to be pulled from the `mvp` branch and merged into the `mvp` branch
