issueDTO.title: Refactor base.html to remove inline styles and move CSS to SCSS file
issueDTO.description:
Refactor base.html to remove inline styles and move CSS to SCSS file

# Description:

The `base.html` template currently contains a large `<style>` block with form styling directly in the HTML file. To improve maintainability and keep styles organized, we should move these styles into the appropriate `.scss` file and remove the inline style block from the HTML.

This is a fast follow from this [PR](https://github.com/Techtonica/techtonica.org/pull/615#pullrequestreview-2711350658)

# Tasks:

- [ ] Move all `<style> `block content from `templates/base.html` into the SCSS file
- [ ] Remove the entire `<style>` block from the HTML file once verified
- [ ] Extract shared styles across application forms into reusable mixins or partials
- [ ] Test to make sure no styles have changed
- [ ] Move form styles to a new partial `_form.scss` file

# Out of Scope:
- Refactoring javascript to its own file
- Refactoring styles of other forms
- Style changes or updates - all styles should be visually unchanged
comments:
I'm excited to apply for the task to refactor the app-reference.html template by moving inline styles to SCSS. With 2???3 years of experience in web development, I have a strong background in HTML, CSS/SCSS, and frontend best practices.

Why I'm a good fit:
??? Proficient in migrating inline styles to modular SCSS partials

??? Experienced in creating reusable mixins for shared form styling

??? Skilled in ensuring visual consistency through thorough testing

??? Strong understanding of frontend maintainability and file structure

My plan:
Move the <style> block content into a new _form.scss partial.

Import it properly into the main SCSS file.

Extract and modularize common form styles for reuse.

Confirm there are no visual regressions.

Remove the inline <style> block once verified.

You can view my GitHub here: https://github.com/Web3Muna

I???d love the opportunity to take this on???thanks for considering!

Best regards,
Newton Muna

issueDTO.title: Enhancing Usability of Date/Time questions on mobile phones
issueDTO.description:
**Nextcloud (please complete the following information):**

- Nextcloud-Version: 30.0.6
- Forms-Version: latest

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In current use cases, forms are filled out by users without Nextcloud accounts on their smartphones (iOS or Android). When using the DatePicker feature, a date view opens that is difficult to navigate via touchscreens. Specifically, entering the correct year proves challenging for users, such as when inputting a date of birth.

~Even when selecting the text field with the restriction ???numbers only???, the input data is only checked when the ???Submit??? button is pressed.~

**Describe the solution you'd like**
_Integrate Native Date Pickers:_  
The DatePicker should utilize the device's native picker on smartphones. This approach would enhance user experience by leveraging familiar interfaces across both iOS and Android platforms, improving ease of use and accuracy.

~_Enhance Number Input Fields:_ 
When a field is set to "numbers only," ensure that the smartphone keyboard exclusively displays numeric options. This will minimize input errors and streamline the data entry process for users.~

**Additional context**
This would significantly improve the usability of the mobile phone and thus minimize incorrect entries by users.
Many thanks!

--- Edit ---
Removed the number input related parts as we already add the correct input type and it's up to the Browser/OS to react on that.
comments:
Hi @tjeyh,

thanks for the feature request. We've already discussed switching the date/time pickers to the native pickers, so it's very likely to happen soon. If you're up for some coding you could also give it a try. This should not be very difficult :)

Regarding the number inputs: did you really set the field in edit mode to the correct type? We're already setting the correct [input type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/input/number) here:

https://github.com/nextcloud/forms/blob/2e6d79798b9734d3579a347f5968a9efc0634428/src/components/Questions/QuestionShort.vue#L29

Hi @Chartman123,
thanks for your quick feedback! :-)

Regarding the number inputs: I may have worded that a little awkwardly.
I mean, if you are using a standard short text field, you can set the option: Numbers only.
When I select this option, the entire keyboard is still displayed on the phone (in my case, iOS Safari). It may be possible to display a native keyboard on the phone that only allows entering numbers.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cd4b2f18-5b46-4ad0-ab28-7fc0e1ddf352)

I hope this helps. :-)
@tjeyh is this the initial presentation of the keyboard or did you switch the shown characters before the screenshot?
@Chartman123 it is the initial presentation of the keyboard.
Ok, thanks, then everything is already working as expected. We can't do more here, it's up to the OS/Browser to react to the set input type and to show the corresponding keyboard layout.
Sorry, closed it too quickly... The date picker part will of course be kept open until it's done :)

> The date picker part will of course be kept open until it's done :)

We could use DateTimePickerNative where possible.
But otherwise it will be fixed if we migrate to Vue 3 due to the new picker.

### What is your request?

As title.

### What is your motivation for this change?

> I just came across this again and I think we **really** need to make the current constructor from `UInt` to `Int` that is implicit be **explicit** - see https://github.com/modular/modular/blob/98efed8a2737dfda71c0d2303b92cb24020c165a/mojo/stdlib/stdlib/builtin/int.mojo#L323-L331
> Any interest in working on that?  Implicit constructor here is a big footgun and we should instead be explicitly casting at call sites.

_Originally posted by @JoeLoser in https://github.com/modular/modular/pull/3753#pullrequestreview-2847771501_
            

### Any other details?

N/A

issueDTO.title: Temp data (170 GB) not cleaned up
issueDTO.description:
Checking my temp folder I noticed lots of files of around 150 MB in size like: 
C:\Users\Mike Wiegand\AppData\Local\Temp\terraform-provider7994040

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7d028fa4-b4cd-45fb-8002-045ef76a5a11)

They total up to more than 170 GB.
comments: Hello and thank you for this issue! The core team regularly reviews new issues and discusses them, but this can take a little time. Please bear with us while we get to your issue. If you're interested, the contribution guide has a section about the [decision-making process](https://github.com/opentofu/opentofu/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#who-decides-if-a-feature-will-be-implemented-and-how-is-that-decision-made).

Thanks for reporting this, @mikeg-de!

These appear to be the temporary locations where OpenTofu downloads a provider package archive before extracting it into the provider cache directory.

There _is_ some code that makes a best-effort to clean these up:

https://github.com/opentofu/opentofu/blob/f8d128491c43e7b246d9de8538e21b383722beba/internal/getproviders/package_location_http_archive.go#L82-L87

However, I notice you are using Windows and so I suspect that what you've observed might be caused by Windows preventing the file from being deleted while it's still open, whereas that is allowed on other platforms that OpenTofu supports.

Due to how `defer` works in Go, these `defer` calls will be visited in _reverse order_ when the function exits, which means that OpenTofu is effectively calling `os.Remove` before it calls `os.Close`. Inverting these so that the `os.Close` call happens before the `os.Remove` call might be sufficient to make this work on Windows, if my theory is correct.

There's some similar treatment in the newly-added `PackageOCIBlobArchive` which seems like it'll have the same problem but for a slightly different reason:

https://github.com/opentofu/opentofu/blob/f8d128491c43e7b246d9de8538e21b383722beba/internal/getproviders/package_location_oci_blob_archive.go#L138-L142

In this case there is _only_ a call to `os.Remove`, and the function is relying on the automatic cleanup that closes the underlying filehandle when an `os.File` object goes out of scope, which would therefore _also_ cause these steps to happen in the wrong order. If I was correct about the cause of the problem in `PackageHTTPURL` then we should update `PackageOCIBlobArchive` to follow the same pattern.

In the meantime: OpenTofu does not rely on these files after provider installation is complete, so you can manually delete them immediately if you need to reclaim that disk space.
We are also skipping checking the return values of both of those functions, which is not ideal.  We should at least be logging the error to help diagnose issues like this one.
can I work on this?

Sure!  Thanks @KrishnaSindhur!

Please take a look through the [Contributing Guide](https://github.com/opentofu/opentofu/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) before getting started.

Hi,

It seems this issue has been inactive for a few weeks.
Would it be okay if I go ahead and work on it, or is someone already actively handling it?

Thanks in advance!

It seems that #2995 resolved this for the HTTP archive implementation, but not for the similar problem in the OCI mirror implementation, so I'm going to reopen this to represent that there's still a little more work to do here.

I'm also unassigning the original assignee since someone else might work on the next PR.
Can I work on it

summary.attemptedFixes: Inverting the order of os.Remove and os.Close, updating PackageOCIBlobArchive to follow the same pattern, and at least logging the error to help diagnose issues like this one.
summary.otherNotes: There is some code that makes a best-effort to clean these up, but it seems to be ineffective due to Windows preventing the file from being deleted while it's still open. Inverting the order of os.Remove and os.Close might be sufficient to make this work on Windows.

issueDTO.title: Port JSON output format for llvm-dwarfdump
issueDTO.description: `llvm-readelf/obj` supports `--elf-output-style=` with JSON as one of the values which makes parsing readelf output much easier. Having the same for `llvm-dwarfdump` would also be nice to have.
comments:
@llvm/issue-subscribers-tools-llvm-dwarfdump

Author: None (PiJoules)

<details>
`llvm-readelf/obj` supports `--elf-output-style=` with JSON as one of the values which makes parsing readelf output much easier. Having the same for `llvm-dwarfdump` would also be nice to have.
</details>

Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

Author: None (PiJoules)

<details>
`llvm-readelf/obj` supports `--elf-output-style=` with JSON as one of the values which makes parsing readelf output much easier. Having the same for `llvm-dwarfdump` would also be nice to have.
</details>
Hi! I'd like to work on this issue. Can you assign it to me? Thank you!@PiJoules

> [@jh7370](https://github.com/jh7370) Thanks! I'm happy to give it a try. In some of my previous work, I???ve dealt with DWARF at a low level ??? specifically, manually parsing the .debug_line section from ELF files using a state machine to map machine code addresses to source line numbers. I???ll start by studying the existing llvm-dwarfdump infrastructure and will post an RFC on Discourse outlining the proposed output format before moving on to implementation.

Sounds good! I'd focus on dumping the different DWARF section types as a first attempt and don't try to implement printing for every section at once. Also, consider how to split the changes into small, easily reviewable chunks rather than having a big monolithic PR with all the changes at once.

> > [@jh7370](https://github.com/jh7370) Thanks! I'm happy to give it a try. In some of my previous work, I???ve dealt with DWARF at a low level ??? specifically, manually parsing the .debug_line section from ELF files using a state machine to map machine code addresses to source line numbers. I???ll start by studying the existing llvm-dwarfdump infrastructure and will post an RFC on Discourse outlining the proposed output format before moving on to implementation.
> 
> Sounds good! I'd focus on dumping the different DWARF section types as a first attempt and don't try to implement printing for every section at once. Also, consider how to split the changes into small, easily reviewable chunks rather than having a big monolithic PR with all the changes at once.

Thanks for the guidance ??? I???ll start by focusing on a few key DWARF sections (e.g. .debug_info, .debug_line) and plan the initial structure accordingly. I???ll also make sure to split the changes into small, reviewable patches rather than one big PR.

Echoing what @jh7370 mentioned, yeah I also think an RFC is good and small incremental changes are nice to review. By no means do I expect this to be done very quickly over a weekend. Definitely reach out if you have any questions.

The assignee should also ensure that the output format is described in the RFC. The issue has no specific validation or requirement other than the assignee's familiarity with the DWARF file format.
summary.attemptedFixes: The assignee has started by studying the existing llvm-dwarfdump infrastructure and will post an RFC on Discourse outlining the proposed output format before moving on to implementation. The assignee has also been advised to focus on dumping different DWARF section types and splitting the changes into small, reviewable chunks.

issueDTO.title: [ja] Umbrella issue for Katacoda removal in Japanese
issueDTO.description:
Upstream: #33936, #41496

## Background

ref. #33936

> (The public part of) Katacoda shut down on June 15, 2022 
> https://www.oreilly.com/online-learning/leveraging-katacoda-technology.html
> ...
> SIG Docs members propose to edit pages that use Katacoda to mark that the sandbox is unavailable. When an alternative is available then update the affected pages to use the alternative.

So we need to remove Katacoda from each page.
For instructions on how to remove it, please refer to the upstream (en) page.

issueDTO.title: Rename `executorch` cmake target to `prim_ops_lib`
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 The feature, motivation and pitch

As titled. The cmake target `executorch` is confusing, it only contains `executorch_core` and `register_prim_ops.cpp`. It would be good if we can change the name to `prim_ops_lib`, following the pattern of `portable_ops_lib` and `optimized_ops_lib`.

After the renaming, it would be good to change `executorch-config.cmake` to add `target_link_options_shared_lib(prim_ops_lib)` there. Then we can get rid of code like: 

https://github.com/pytorch/executorch/blob/main/examples/models/llama/CMakeLists.txt#L82-L83

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### RFC (Optional)

_No response_
comments: Hi! I'd love to work on this issue as my first contribution. Could you please assign it to me or let me know if it's okay to proceed?

This is also nice because it frees up executorch as a target name for an "everything I configured" target, which I've wanted to add. It does technically break BC to rename this, but to be honest, I think it's worth doing and calling out in release notes.

> Hi! I'd love to work on this issue as my first contribution. Could you please assign it to me or let me know if it's okay to proceed?

Sure, thanks. I've assigned the issue to you.
@JawadKhan65 Just wanted to ping on this. Is this still something you're interested in working on? If not, no worries. Feel free to reach out if you're blocked or have any questions.

issueDTO.title: RNNoise Implementation for better noise reduction
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request

Any feasibility in implementing rnnoise for the audio noise suppression?
https://jmvalin.ca/demo/rnnoise/

From Claude.ai:

> Implementation steps:
> 
> Compile RNNoise to WebAssembly using Emscripten [Webmachinelearning](https://webmachinelearning.github.io/webnn-samples/rnnoise/)[Dreamwidth](https://jmvalin.dreamwidth.org/15210.html)
> Use Web Audio API to create an audio processing pipeline that intercepts the microphone stream, processes it through RNNoise, and outputs a cleaned MediaStream [Medium](https://tagdiwalaviral.medium.com/struggles-of-noise-reduction-in-rtc-part-2-2526f8179442)[GitHub](https://github.com/webrtcsdk/webrtcsdk)
> Replace the original getUserMedia stream with the processed one

### Pros

Better noise suppression on-par with Jitsi.

### Additional context

_No response_
comments:
It would be great to have built-in noise suppression. However, MiroTalk SFU does support external noise suppression tools, as described in this post:

👉 [Best Noise Suppression, Cancelling, and Removal](https://mirotalk.hashnode.dev/best-noise-suppression-cancelling-and-removal)

You can simply install one of the recommended apps and select it as the audio input source from the MiroTalk SFU device options.

There is also a mention of MiroTalk SFU supporting external noise suppression tools.

issueDTO.title: Recipe to avoid concatenating with empty String to perform type conversion
issueDTO.description:
## What problem are you trying to solve?

Code readability and possibly performance when using the `"" + ...` trick to convert something to a String.
`String.valueOf()` is a better alternative.

## Describe the situation before applying the recipe
<!-- Ideally as a self-contained code example, as a start to the recipe unit tests. -->
```java
"" + 1
```

## Describe the situation after applying the recipe
<!-- Ideally as a self-contained code example, as a start to the recipe unit tests. -->
```java
String.valueOf(1)
```

## OSS repro
- https://github.com/encryptedsystems/Clusion/blob/d6f89c1269f618ec42a9bfc42e940382fa14ae69/src/main/java/org/crypto/sse/DynRR.java#L47
- https://github.com/xebialabs/overcast/blob/8a494dc8f8572ae337ce91b06829eb9567c91f5d/src/main/java/com/xebialabs/overcast/host/CachedLibvirtHost.java#L57
comments: Hi! I'd like to work on this issue. Let me know if it's still available. Thanks!
It sure is. I suggest you start with forking the repo, creating a branch with unit test with a few cases showing the desired behavior.

Here's a quick first attempt:
- https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite-static-analysis/pull/634/
Just to clarify, since the PR #634 is now open and seems to fully address this, should I consider this issue closed or still open for contribution?

issueDTO.title: Popup buttons missing visible focused state indicator on keyboard navigation in Chrome
issueDTO.description:
To reproduce:

1. Using Chrome, navigate to some site
2. Click on PB's icon in the browser toolbar. If you don't see PB's icon on the toolbar, look for it inside the "puzzle piece" icon menu.
3. Click inside the popup (related bug: #3105)
4. Start pressing <kbd>Tab</kbd>
5. Observe that the "trackers" link gets a focus highlight
6. Press <kbd>Tab</kbd> again to put focus on the "Disable for this site" button
7. Observe that there is (almost) no visible highlight on the button in Chrome

Affected buttons (`pbButton` class buttons):

- Disable for this site / Enable for this site
- Report Broken Site
- Send report
- Cancel
- Copy to clipboard

We need to make sure the focus highlight is visible in light and dark modes on both Chrome and Firefox.

issueDTO.title: Revise missing history warning for item-item (and other components)
issueDTO.description:
Right now, `ItemKNNScorer` (and probably other components) emit a warning if the user history is `None`, suggesting a history component may be missing.

However, this will also be emitted if the user is unknown in the training data, creating false positives.

We should revise this warning logic to reduce those false positives, possibly by warning if the query is not a `RecQuery`.

issueDTO.title: pixi CLI should support showing the packages intalled in a global env
issueDTO.description:
### Problem description

After running `pixi global install foo`, it appears that the pixi CLI does not currently support showing the packages that were installed in foo's environment.

I checked `pixi global`, `pixi list`, and `pixi tree` and did not see any way to do this.

Too often something stops working when a new version of a transitive dependency is installed. Implementing this feature would make it easier to debug situations like this.
comments:
That makes sense, especially the `pixi global list` and `pixi global tree` is something I'm missing too!

This should not be to complex, we're open to contributions!

Hi! I was considering contributing by tackling this issue, but from what I see it might already be implemented, assuming I understood the original description of the issue correctly. If I install a package like `pixi global install pixi-pack`, it creates a global environment with the same name which can be seen with `pixi global list`. Then, if I run `pixi global list --environment pixi-pack`, I can see a full list of the dependencies included in this environment, as shown in the following screenshot: It should also be documented via an example [here](https://pixi.sh/latest/reference/cli/pixi/global/list/#examples), although I think the description of the `--environment` could be improved. Also, this only applies to `list` - whereas I think `pixi global tree --environment ` is something currently not implemented anyhow.

repository.description: Package management made easy
repository.name: pixi

summary.main: Implement a feature in the pixi CLI to show packages installed in a global environment, making it easier to debug situations where a new version of a transitive dependency is installed.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires the CLI to support showing packages installed in a global environment, and possibly implementing a `pixi global tree --environment <env>` command.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the description or comments
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to debugging situations where a new version of a transitive dependency is installed, and the CLI does not currently support showing the packages installed in a global environment. The feature would make it easier to debug such situations.

issueDTO.title: BUG: assert_frame_equal(check_dtype=False) fails when comparing two DFs containing pd.NA that only differ in dtype (object vs Int32)
issueDTO.description:
### Pandas version checks

- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [ ] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [main branch](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas) of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
import pandas as pd
from pandas.testing import assert_frame_equal

df1 = pd.DataFrame(
    {
        "x": pd.Series([pd.NA], dtype="Int32"),
    }
)
df2 = pd.DataFrame(
    {
        "x": pd.Series([pd.NA], dtype="object"),
    }
)

assert_frame_equal(df1, df2, check_dtype=False) # fails, but should succeed
```

### Issue Description

Output of the above example:

```
AssertionError: DataFrame.iloc[:, 0] (column name="x") are different

DataFrame.iloc[:, 0] (column name="x") values are different (100.0 %)
[index]: [0]
[left]:  [nan]
[right]: [<NA>]
```

When comparing DataFrames containing `pd.NA` using `check_dtype=False`, the test incorrectly fails despite the only difference being the dtype (Int32 vs object).

Note that the values in the dataframe really are the same:

```
print(type(df1["x"][0])) # prints <class 'pandas._libs.missing.NAType'>
print(type(df2["x"][0])) # prints <class 'pandas._libs.missing.NAType'>
```

Related issues:
- https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/18463: Similar but "opposite": here the dataframes contain different values (nan vs None) which are incorrectly treated as equal. In this issue, the dataframes contain equal values which are incorrectly treated as different.

### Expected Behavior

The test should succeed, since the only difference is the dtypes, and `check_dtype=False`.

### Installed Versions

<details>

pandas                : 2.2.3
numpy                 : 1.26.4
pytz                  : 2025.2
dateutil              : 2.9.0.post0
pip                   : 24.0
Cython                : None
sphinx                : None
IPython               : None
adbc-driver-postgresql: None
adbc-driver-sqlite    : None
bs4                   : None
blosc                 : None
bottleneck            : None
dataframe-api-compat  : None
fastparquet           : None
fsspec                : None
html5lib              : None
hypothesis            : None
gcsfs                 : None
jinja2                : 3.1.6
lxml.etree            : None
matplotlib            : None
numba                 : None
numexpr               : None
odfpy                 : None
openpyxl              : 3.1.5
pandas_gbq            : None
psycopg2              : None
pymysql               : None
pyarrow               : 19.0.1
pyreadstat            : None
pytest                : 8.3.5
python-calamine       : None
pyxlsb                : None
s3fs                  : None
scipy                 : None
sqlalchemy            : 2.0.41
tables                : None
tabulate              : None
xarray                : None
xlrd                  : None
xlsxwriter            : None
zstandard             : 0.23.0
tzdata                : 2025.2
qtpy                  : None
pyqt5                 : None

</details>
comments:
Thanks for the report, this would pass if when converting the EA to a NumPy array we cast to object dtype. I haven't looked to see if this might cause issues in other cases. Since this is aimed at tests, I'm wondering if changing to object dtype is okay here.

cc @jbrockmendel @mroeschke for any thoughts.

> this would pass if when converting the EA to a NumPy array we cast to object dtype

Yah I'm pretty sure that the behavior of `df1['x'].to_numpy()` casting to a float dtype was a much-discussed intentional decision.  Changing that would be a can of worms.

I'm inclined to just discourage the use of a) check_dtype=False and b) using pd.NA in an object dtype column (note that `df1 == df2` raises)

@jbrockmendel - sorry, I wasn't clear. I meant just inside `assert_frame_equal` to use `.to_numpy(dtype="object")` when `check_dtype=False` rather than just `.to_numpy()`. Agreed changing the behavior of `.to_numpy()` is off the table.
Gotcha, fine by me
how can i make contribution to solve this, can you please give advice to me? @iabhi4 @rhshadrach

Hi @venturero 

I already raised a PR for this based on the above discussion. You can checkout other issues from the `Issues` tab and follow the [contribution guide](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/development/contributing.html) to submit a clean fix for the issue you're tackling.

issueDTO.title: Possible Swagger page on local server?
issueDTO.description:
Hello!

First of all, thanks a lot for making this nice application, and keeping it free :)

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Not a problem, but some quality of life improvements. It would be nice to be able to test the API calls on a local server in my browser.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like the Swagger page accessible on the local device IP, for example, HTTP://[ device-ip ]:8080/docs

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I'm using CURL right now, but it is very cumbersome to create the correct request.
I can see the API specification on https://capcom6.github.io/android-sms-gateway/, but I can't seem to edit the [ device-ip ] to my device IP. I'm not sure if it's even allowed.

**Additional context**
n/a
comments:
Hello!

Thank you for your feature request and for your kind words about the project!

I've added this suggestion to my backlog for consideration.

To help me better understand your needs, could you please elaborate on your specific use case? Are you looking to use Swagger UI primarily to generate cURL commands, or do you want to make API calls directly through the Swagger interface? Note that cURL commands are displayed in Swagger UI even if the UI itself can't execute requests directly.

Regarding the public Swagger documentation: By default, Swagger UI doesn't allow dynamically changing server addresses from the interface. Even if it did, browser CORS restrictions would likely prevent connections to a local server.

Hey! Thanks for your reply

I would like to make an API call directly through the Swagger interface. I'm currently playing with the FAST Api, and it saves a lot of headaches as the Swagger/OpenAPI allows me to test the API and responses directly in the browser.

Of course, curl commands are available in the browser, I'm copying them right now.

But it would be a nice quality-of-life improvement if we could bypass copy/pasting commands in Windows Terminal/PowerShell. I've always found Windows Terminal/PS doesn't like pasting multiline commands.

Again, this would be _nice to have, not a need to have_ ;)
This issue is stale because it has been open for 7 days with no activity.

issueDTO.title: Provide a way to enable both quantity_support and time_support in one go
issueDTO.description: In https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/8782 we discussed that it would be nice to have a way to enable both ``time_support`` and ``quantity_support``, maybe e.g. ``astropy_support``.
comments:
Actually the `contextlib.contexmanager` implementation also allows using it as a decorator

quoting from https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.contextmanager
> [contextmanager()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.contextmanager) uses [ContextDecorator](https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.ContextDecorator) so the context managers it creates can be used as decorators as well as in [with](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/compound_stmts.html#with) statements. When used as a decorator, a new generator instance is implicitly created on each function call (this allows the otherwise ???one-shot??? context managers created by [contextmanager()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.contextmanager) to meet the requirement that context managers support multiple invocations in order to be used as decorators).

So my preference is to go with the first approach as it's simpler. Note that it is generally not recommended to call so-called dunder[^1] methods like `__enter__` and `__exit__` directly, so I would favor something like:

```python
from contextlib import contextmanager, ExitStack

@contextmanager
def astro_support():
    with ExitStack() as stack:
        stack.enter_context(quantity_support())
        stack.enter_context(time_support())
        yield
```

[^1]: "dunder" is short for "double underscore" and is a common way to refer to Python's protocols that are named with two leading and two trailing underscores
Yes, this works perfectly. I have opened a PR #17575. I will update the changelog and add a test case shortly!

Hi @astropy/core team 👋
I'd love to help close out issue???#8860 (???enable both quantity_support and time_support in one go???). I saw PR???#17979 is already addressing this great start!
I can help with:

Adding unit tests (both context manager and decorator use cases)
Updating the visualization documentation
Would it be helpful if I take this on next?

Thanks for pointing out #17979, which we apparently missed entirely. We'd actually prefer to get both code and tests in the same PR, so I'd like to see if @elmostafa-abdelaal is still interested in this after month of not hearing back from us. In case there's no response (which would be understandable given the circumstances) after a reasonable amount of time (say a couple weeks at least), you (@Subham-KRLX) would be welcome to take this on, possibly starting from where things are now in #17979 and adding a test (but please don't forget to keep @elmostafa-abdelaal as a commit author if you do !). Thanks for your interest and patience.

Thanks for the update I totally understand waiting to hear back from @elmostafa-abdelaal it makes sense to give them first dibs since they???ve already put work into #17979.
If it???s helpful I am happy to:
Help draft tests/docs in the meantime (maybe start a WIP branch?),Jump in later if needed while crediting their commits or Just review whenever the PR moves forward.
Whatever works best for the team just let me know.

issueDTO.title: Replace ??-related bound constants with `next_up` / `next_down`
issueDTO.description:
### Background
Rust 1.86 stabilized [f64::{next_up, next_down}](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f64.html#method.next_up) and [f32::{next_down, next_up}](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f32.html#method.next_up), so we can now replace several hardcoded floating-point constants using these methods. Replacing manually defined constants with std library can improve clarity and correctness.

See several functions starting from 
https://github.com/apache/datafusion/blob/a089eff251f13ac52ba070dbdf67cc20d7851662/datafusion/common/src/scalar/mod.rs#L1191-L1202

and https://github.com/apache/datafusion/blob/main/datafusion/common/src/scalar/consts.rs
### Solution 
1. Update related functions in `datafusion/common/src/scalar/mod.rs` 
2. Verify that the updated values match the current constants, or document any small differences that arise due to precision changes.

I think this is a good first issue :) 

The TODO comment is originally added in https://github.com/apache/datafusion/pull/11584
comments: take

Hi everyone! 👋 This will be my first open-source contribution, and I???m super excited to get involved with DataFusion :) I???d like to take on this issue and will start setting up my local environment today. Please let me know if there???s anything specific I should keep in mind as a first-time contributor!

issueDTO.title: Switch from Flake8/isort/Black to Ruff for linting and formatting
issueDTO.description:
### What is the problem or limitation you are having?

This repository currently uses Flake8/isort/Black for code linting and formatting.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Ruff should replace Flake8/isort/Black as the code linter and formatter.

This should be done as follows:
1. Add Ruff configuration to `pyproject.toml` as included [here](https://github.com/beeware/toga/blob/780d1db68e68315ecc064c87caeca069692ca1b0/pyproject.toml#L53-L69)
2. Add Ruff checks to `.pre-commit-config.yaml` as included [here](https://github.com/beeware/toga/blob/780d1db68e68315ecc064c87caeca069692ca1b0/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L12-L17)
3. Remove the `[tool.isort]` configuration section from `pyproject.toml`. 
4. Remove `[flake8]` configuration section from `tox.ini`.
5. Run `pre-commit run -a` in the repo directory, and let Ruff do any formatting or linting that it can do automatically.
6. You will almost certainly end up with a list of errors, each identified by an error number.
7. In this PR, you will not be making any significant code changes.
8. Add a global `ignore` list to `pyproject.toml` in the `[tool.ruff.lint]` section, below the `extend-select` configuration section, including *only the rules that apply to this repository*. You can find an example of an `ignore` list [here](https://github.com/beeware/briefcase/blob/1ffd045752d3a3d920a68d920201d890e8637e49/pyproject.toml#L255-L267). Include a comment next to the rule indicating what it relates to, as shown.
9. Run `pre-commit run -a` to ensure that all the rules are being successfully ignored.
10. Add `.ruff_cache` to the [`.gitignore` file](https://github.com/beeware/beeware/blob/main/.gitignore).
11. There may be some minor code changes necessary because Flake8 and Black don't always agree; these changes should be kept to a minimum.
12. Submit the pull request.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

None.

### Additional context

Once the initial PR is merged, the next step in this process is to begin working through resolving the errors indicated by the rules. 

Each rule begins with a letter or set of letters. Each set of rules that begins with the same letter or letters is related. For example, errors `B007`, `B018`, and `B904` are part of the same ruleset. 

Each set of related rules should be worked through together, and submitted as a separate PR for each set of related rules, i.e. submit a PR for the `BXXX` rules, and a separate PR for the `EXXX` rules.

The `SIMXXX` checks are explicitly disabled in the configuration. Do not remove the commented out `SIM` check, and avoid resolving the `SIMXXX` errors.

issueDTO.title: Mention `ReadBufferEachConn` and `WriteBufferEachConn` on README
issueDTO.description:
Hello,

I try to use the ping command regularly to check if the rueidis client is disconnected or reconnected, but I found that if there are a lot of redis servers, ping will cause the memory to keep rising. Through the go pprof tool, I found that bufio.NewWriteSize and bufio.NewReadSize occupy a lot of memory. What is the reason for this?

I know rueidis has already implemented an automatic detection method for reconnection internally, and if the ping command for periodic detection is incorrect, how should we know if redis client is disconnected for the application layer?
comments:
Hi @zhaozekunssss, a PING request will be send to one random redis server and cause one connection be established. One connection will have one reader buffer and one writer buffer which are both 0.5MiB by default.

I guess that???s why you saw your memory usage kept raising, but the raising should stop once all server connections were established.

You can change the default sizes by setting ReadBufferEachConn and WriteBufferEachConn:
https://github.com/redis/rueidis/blob/37dfd476d5eec53699faee1549c8dd45af58ed9a/rueidis.go#L161-L164

> how should we know if redis client is disconnected for the application layer?

Applications can only notice disconnections when they get network errors from trying to interact with connections. So, doing periodic PINGs is correct, but rueidis already does that for you. If you want to do something else when there are connection issues, you can also monitor each redis response to see if it is a network error.

Hi @rueian , thanks for your reply, I have modified the values of ReadBufferEachConn and WriteBufferEachConn, and the memory usage has been reduced to a very low value??????
However, I would like to know why the default values of these two parameters need to be so large, and what their specific functions are? Will this memory be cleared?

Those buffers help the client avoid unnecessary read and write system calls to the TCP connections when handling a large amount of concurrent requests and large pipelines. Therefore, the default values are relatively big. Those buffers will only be cleared after disconnections.

A follow-up to this issue could be adding a description of `ReadBufferEachConn` and `WriteBufferEachConn` to the https://github.com/redis/rueidis?tab=readme-ov-file#memory-consumption-consideration section.

Hi @rueian, another question, since we deployed in a memory sensitive environment, I set the ClientOption.RiscaleEachConn to 8 and found that newRing() still occupies some memory, about 8M.
How about setting it to 6? Will it cause any other problems? We are willing to reduce some throughput.
Hi @zhaozekunssss, it will only affect the upper bound of the throughput. Setting to 5 or lower is ok if you are willing to reduce some throughput.

repository.description: A fast Golang Redis client that supports Client Side Caching, Auto Pipelining, Generics OM, RedisJSON, RedisBloom, RediSearch, etc.
repository.name: rueidis

summary.main: the main goal of the issue is to understand why the memory usage of rueidis client increases when using ping command and how to reduce it
summary.validationOrRequirement: the default values of ReadBufferEachConn and WriteBufferEachConn should be adjusted according to the environment, and the memory usage should be monitored
summary.attemptedFixes: the default values of ReadBufferEachConn and WriteBufferEachConn are changed to reduce memory usage, and ClientOption.RiscaleEachConn is also set to 8 and then 6
summary.otherNotes: the issue is about the memory usage of rueidis client and how to reduce it, especially when using ping command to check redis connection
